The failure to return the personal property to the place specified in the agreement is prima facie evidence of an intent to defraud the lessor or to retain possession of such property without the lessorï¿½s permission. It is a complete defense to any civil action arising out of or involving the arrest or detention of any person upon whom such demand was made that the person failed to return the personal property to any place of business of the lessor within 20 days after such demand.

section.heading: Unlawful receipt of fee, salary, deposit or money to obtain loan for another; penalties.

content.p: It is unlawful for a person to receive an advance fee, salary, deposit or money to obtain a loan for another unless the person places the advance fee, salary, deposit or money in escrow pending completion of the loan or a commitment for the loan. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Advance payments to cover reasonably estimated costs paid to third persons are excluded from the provisions of subsection 1 if the person making them first signs a written agreement which specifies the estimated costs by item and the estimated aggregate cost, and which recites that money advanced for costs will not be refunded. If an itemized service is not performed and the estimated cost thereof is not refunded, the recipient of the advance payment is subject to the penalties provided in subsection 3. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person who violates the provisions of this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is guilty of a misdemeanor if the amount is less than $1,200; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is guilty of a category D felony if the amount is $1,200 or more and shall be punished as provided inNRS 193.130.

section.heading: Qualified intermediaries of clients with certain property: Unlawful acts; criminal penalty; civil penalty.

content.p: It is unlawful for a person to enter into an agreement to act as a qualified intermediary, as defined in 26 C.F.R. ï¿½ 1.1031
, for a client whose relinquished property is located in this State unless: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The proceeds from the disposition of the relinquished property are deposited into a qualified escrow account or qualified trust as defined in 26 C.F.R. ï¿½ 1.1031
. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The money is held in such a manner that it may not be withdrawn from the qualified escrow account or qualified trust without the written approval of the intermediary and the client. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person who violates the provisions of this section is guilty of a category D felony and shall be punished as provided inNRS 193.130. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In addition to any other penalty imposed, the court shall order a person who violates subsection 1 to pay a civil penalty of not less than $10,000. The money so collected: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Must be stated separately on the courtï¿½s docket; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Must be remitted forthwith to the Commissioner of Financial Institutions.

section.heading: Unlawful possession, making, altering, forgery or counterfeiting of sales receipt or inventory pricing label; penalties.

content.p: A person shall not, with the intent to cheat or defraud a retailer, possess, make, alter, forge or counterfeit any sales receipt or inventory pricing label. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Unless a greater penalty is imposed by a specific statute and except as otherwise provided in subsection 3, a person who violates any provision of subsection 1 is guilty of a category E felony and shall be punished as provided inNRS 193.130. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Unless a greater penalty is imposed by a specific statute, a person who violates any provision of subsection 1 and who possesses 15 or more fraudulent sales receipts or inventory pricing labels is guilty of a category D felony and shall be punished as provided inNRS 193.130. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

As used in this section, ï¿½inventory pricing labelï¿½ includes, without limitation, any written or electronic record or label used by a retailer to identify, inventory or price any product or item it offers for sale.

section.heading: Unlawful possession, manufacture, sale or distribution of theft detection shielding device or theft detection device deactivator; penalty.

content.p: A person shall not, with the intent to commit, aid or abet a theft, possess any theft detection shielding device or theft detection device deactivator. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person shall not, with the intent to commit, aid or abet a theft, manufacture, sell or distribute any theft detection shielding device or theft detection device deactivator. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a category D felony and shall be punished as provided inNRS 193.130. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Theft detection device deactivatorï¿½ includes, without limitation, any tool or device designed to allow, or capable of allowing, the deactivation or removal of a theft detection device from any merchandise. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Theft detection shielding deviceï¿½ includes, without limitation, any laminated or coated bag or device intended to shield merchandise from detection by an electronic or magnetic theft detector.

section.heading: Mail theft; penalties; definitions.

content.p: A person commits the crime of mail theft if the person: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Knowingly, willfully and with the intent to deprive, injure, damage or defraud another: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Takes, destroys, hides or embezzles mail; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Buys, receives, conceals or possesses: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any key suited to any lock adopted by the United States Postal Service that provides access to any mail receptacle in any neighborhood or apartment panel used for the purpose of centralized mail; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A counterfeit device or key designed to provide access to a lock described in subparagraph
; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Knowingly, willfully and with the intent to steal any mail inside, damages, opens, tears down, takes or destroys any mail receptacle. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A person who violates any provision of subsection 1 is guilty of a category D felony and shall be punished as provided inNRS 193.130. In addition to any other penalty, the court shall order the person to pay restitution. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The postal customer leaves for collection by the postal service; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The postal service delivers to the postal customer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Mail receptacleï¿½ means a mailbox, post office box, rural box, letter box, lock drawer or any place or area intended or used by postal customers or a postal service for the collection, deposit or delivery of mail. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Postal serviceï¿½ means the United States Postal Service or a private common mail carrier.

section.heading: Determination of value of loss from crime; notice to victim; order of restitution deemed judgment to collect damages.

content.p: A person who is convicted of violating any provision ofNRS 205.060or205.2175to205.2705, inclusive, is civilly liable for the value of any property stolen and not recovered in its original condition. The value of the property must be determined by its retail value or fair market value at the time the crime was committed, whichever is greater. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person who is convicted of any other crime involving damage to property is civilly liable for the amount of damage done to the property. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The prosecutor shall notify the victim concerning the disposition of the criminal charges against the defendant within 30 days after the disposition. The notice must be sent to the last known address of the victim. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An order of restitution signed by the judge in whose court the conviction was entered shall be deemed a judgment against the defendant for the purpose of collecting damages. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Nothing in this section prohibits a victim from recovering additional damages from the defendant.
